job_title: Scientific Research Assistant in Nanaimo, BC
pros: Great variety of fieldwork Positive people and place
cons: Quiet, small university Opportunities to grow more limited

job_title: Career Services Advisor in Nanaimo, BC
pros: Amazing support from management, fun and dynamic work environment
cons: I cant think of any cons specifically, it is more about fit for the role. Its a busy role and you need to wear many hats. It is important to understand that there is a high level of collaboration, social interaction and expectations for engagement in this role. Not an extrovert? Ask lots of questions at the interview :)

pros: Students are wonderful to interact with.
cons: It is seasonal work so hard to plan for.

review_title: The management is very welcoming. They do offer multi-levels of training in all aspects.
job_title: Career Studio Peer Facilitator in Nanaimo, BC
pros: Positive work culture, Load management
cons: No free parking at any time

pros: Flexibility in schedule and work arrangements
cons: Poor pay for level of responsibility.

pros: Small class sizes & freedom to teach what and how you want.
cons: Low pay, very little administrative support or transparency, little to no feedback or mentorship for new faculty, poor benefits package (dental is good though).

job_title: Office Services Coordinator in Nanaimo, BC
pros: Strong leadership, work life balance, professional development opportunities
cons: relatively low pay, many offices are understaffed for the required work load

pros: Excellent salary and benefits. Good co-workers and students. Beautiful location.
cons:
Faculty union regularly sends out articles which are quite racist under the guise of anti-racism. 
Some unhealthy workplace dynamics that management doesn't have the capacity to manage well. As with most universities, managers seem to be spread very thin with workloads beyond their reasonable capacity.

review_title: Dream jobs - for grade two dropouts!
pros: Great location, decent benefits (pension, vacation, etc.), work-life balance
cons: Low compensation (especially considering the cost of living on Vancouver Island), little to no upward mobility

job_title: Animal Care Technician in Nanaimo, BC
pros: they have good health benefit packages
cons: the union fee is high

pros: Fun job with great people and can do homework
cons: None besides the minimum wage

pros: small class teaching environment conducive to learning
cons: pay less than other larger universities

pros: Community support and flexible schedule.
cons: No disadvantages about this position.

pros:
Good pension, salary, holidays, benefits. 
Great team.
cons: I can't really think of any.

pros: Great location; vibrant, multicultural campus;
cons: Relatively lower salaries; too much organizational politics; difficult union-management relations

pros: Flexible schedule, great coworkers and management
cons: Start with minimum wage first

pros: Lovely campus with a great view. Like other places, lots of students who are eager to learn.
cons:
Old boys club. 
Too many inexperienced administrators. Prof to dean to VP in no time!  VPs pay lip service and do not follow up. 
Harassment and bullying is not dealt with for fear of drawing attention to the dept/faculty.  The weird concept of working part time for four semesters turning into a ‘regularized’ position.  That means regularized positions don’t get advertised to attract the best possible candidates.  
Change occurs at a snail’s pace if at all. 
Underfunded. Very low salaries. Infrastructure needs work. Parking is far too expensive.  
The university accepts anyone so drop out is high.

job_title: Coordinator, International Marketing & Recruitment in Nanaimo, BC
pros:
I absolutely loved this job and my role within the Faculty of International Education at VIU. There has been an influx of new staff during my 3.5 years, which has led to new ideas, processes and positive change. There is certainly a growing cohesiveness amongst the different areas of the international department (the international retreat that occurs every June has been particularly effective at improving inter-departmental relationships). Support from the international marketing team and senior management has been phenomenal throughout my time. 

VIU's popularity and reputation as a desirable place of study is increasing rapidly all over the globe, and I don't see this abating any time soon. As a result of this burgeoning notoriety, I suspect the international department will continue to grow in size and scope. 

In closing, I'll just add that the future looks bright for VIU. Keep up the great work! 

(I'm writing this as a current employee but will be leaving my position in a week from now - I'd have remained in this position far longer if it weren't for the need to move in with my partner in Metro Vancouver).
cons: Some kinks in IT need to be worked out, particularly in the Admissions area, but gaps have been identified and should be closed in the coming months.

job_title: Peer Supported Learning Leader in Nanaimo, BC
pros: Part-time work that applied what i knew, hard to ask for more. As a learning leader for one year, I matured by remaining rigorously organized to planning and hosting the sessions. . I felt like I was in a position to change peoples lives, so I went all out on the sessions. The students learned and formed bonds among one another. Me, the PSL Leader , was just proud of their performance.
cons: The pressure and stress can be immense at certain times during the semester. Sometimes you want to give up. Don't be the PSL leader who misses a week because everyone is relying on you. You gotta have GUTS to get through it.

pros: Climate, amazing view, vacation time, benefits/pension make up for the non-competitive salaries.   Some departments get along quite well, and people tend to be positive.  Some areas allow flex-time schedules.
cons: Seems resources are always devoted to certain areas, salaries are not as competitive as larger areas.  Not much chance to advance unless you are in the "old boys' club" - some individuals have advanced with no apparent competition.  Public transportation is terrible and parking rates continue to increase.

review_title: They ask you for everything, but treat you like crap.
pros: The people there are mostly good, and the benefits are quite tough to beat. It's also a beautiful part of the world. You will have a few very good, very nice students.
cons: The administration is really money driven. They will try to nickel and dime you constantly. Some of the infrastructure is really dated (unless you're in business, then it's a different purse).

review_title: Temporary Professor is a steep learning curve.
pros: It's great to mold the minds of university students, and the fellow profs assisted as best they could to help advise. Department heads kept in touch.
cons: Very limited structure and course layout was only partially predetermined. Limited budgets for supplies and equipment make it hard to teach anything truly interesting without risking one's own equipment.

pros: Employees receive reasonable compensation along with government benefits and pension. There's also the prestige of working for a public post-secondary, and if you're in one of the unions or the Faculty Association, you have some job security.
cons: Working at VIU is bureaucratic, patriarchal, and stultifying. While they have all kinds of policies in place and embrace an equal opportunity workplace in theory - in practice there are a small group at the top controlling things and ensuring that top positions get filled by people that will support the current cartel.

review_title: A very clicky group place to work.
pros: If you can just follow orders and not get involved in the union you can work here.
cons: The union is hopeless and there is a pecking order not only within the union but outside of it as well.  Your job, unless you have degree's and diploma's galore, you will be at the bottom of the pecking order and subject to being bumped with no or very little options.

review_title: I performed a few part time roles within Professional Development and Training.
pros: The last team I worked with was superb. We worked together and got along very well. It was a career highlight for me. I found that once I got in with one part time role and could show I worked well, it wasn't hard to find more part time roles.
cons: Many employees nearing or at retirement meant lots of turnover. If I was aiming to stay long term that might feel disruptive.

pros:
Building and amenities to services like the gymnasium, culinary arts, pub
Campus events
Amazing location - mountain and ocean views, surrounding areas of gardens and marshes
Employment benefits and professional development opp.
cons: Non really many, but perhaps too many upper level administrative staff!

pros: I started here right out of the ABT Program i took here. I love the people I work with, I love the location of the University, I love that employees can take courses for free. Many reason I love it here.
cons: The stairs on some days are hard...

pros:
* View and location
* Uneficient processes generate more jobs
* Extra week off at Christmas
* Easy work if you are looking for no challenge
cons:
* Human resources department is flawed and that effects the entire University. If you have an opportunity to chat with people from different departments, that is the general message.
* Higher management makes the big money, all admin assistants CUPE staff will top at $25/hr but mostly if you have an "in" with management.

pros: Best employer in town. I would work there forever if I could stay in town.
cons: There are a lot of committees, but they get work done so it's not that bad.

pros: Easy commute, beautiful views from campus, nice scenery.
cons: Terrible transit system, no pay increases, lack of growth opportunities.

review_title: A great little campus-community radio station and media organization.
pros: It's fun, and a great learning opportunity.
cons: Small budget, never enough resources.

pros: Gorgeous campus, wonderful colleagues and professional development opportunities.
cons: Parking is expensive and lots can be full.

pros: Very supportive staff and friendly environment.
cons: I have not found any cons yet :)

pros: Left alone to tutor the best way I saw fit
